questions.text: The opening in the central tendon of the diaphragm transmits ______
questions.solution:
The right phrenic nerve passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm, either by the caval hiatus or just lateral to it.

The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm anterior to the central tendon, just lateral to the left cardiac surface and more anterior than the right phrenic nerve.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Located in

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through

 

Inferior Vena cava

Right phrenic nerve 

Oesophagus

Vagus nerve- right and left

Aorta

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

 

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Primary active transport is mediated by which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
The primary active transport is mediated by Na+-K+ ATPase.

In active transport, the energy is provided almost exclusively by the hydrolysis of ATP. Hence active transport is mediated by ATPases (eg. Na+-K+-ATPase), enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of ATP.

Carrier proteins can mediate both primary and secondary active transports while the Na/K-ATPase is a primary active transport protein.

PRIMARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT SECONDARY ACTIVE TRANSPORT
Requires direct input of metabolic energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)   The transport of two or more solutes is coupled and metabolic energy is provided  indirectly from the Na+ gradient that is maintained across cell membranes by the Na+-K+-ATPase pump

a) Na+-K+-ATPase or sodium-potassium pump

b) Ca2+-ATPase

c) H+-ATPase (proton pump)

d) H+-K+-ATPase

a) Na+- glucose cotransport (SGLT)

b) Na+-Ca2+ counter transport

Other options :

Option A: G-proteins are molecular switches inside cells that transmit signals from receptors to trigger cellular responses. They play a crucial role in processes like hormone signalling, sensory perception, and cell growth.

Option C: Carrier proteins are membrane proteins that transport specific molecules across cell membranes by binding to them and undergoing conformational changes. They facilitate the movement of substances like ions, glucose, and amino acids into or out of cells.

Option D: Channel proteins are membrane proteins that form pores, allowing the passive movement of specific ions or molecules across the cell membrane. They facilitate processes like ion flow in nerve cells and water transport in kidney cells.

Related Pearl: Glucose Transporters

 

Function

Major sites of expression

Secondary active transport

(Na + -glucose cotransport)

    

SGLT 1

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Absorption of glucose

Renal tubules

Facilitated diffusion

    

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Fructose transport

Jejunum, sperm

questions.text: Which of the following forms complex I of the electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
Complex I of the electron transport chain (ETC) is NADH-Q oxidoreductase.

The ETC constitutes 4 enzyme complexes:

  • Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase
  • Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase
  • Complex III: Q-cytochrome c oxidoreductase
  • Complex IV: cytochrome c oxidase

Components of complex I: FMN and Fe-S complex 

Mechanism: NADH-Q oxidoreductase catalyzes the transfer of electrons, from NADH to coenzyme Q, along with the transfer of four H+ across the membrane.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bilateral adnexal masses and ascites. Histopathological examination of resected specimen shows sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. The most likely diagnosis is ____.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis with the above clinical interpretation is metastatic signet-ring carcinoma called Krukenberg tumor.

  • Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic signet-ring cell adenocarcinoma of the ovary, accounting for 1% to 2% of all ovarian tumors.
  • Primary sites: Stomach (70%); Carcinomas of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma)
  • Often bilateral
  • Microscopically, it is composed chiefly of mucin-laden signet-ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei.

Image showing metastastic signet-ring cells in Krukenberg tumor

questions.text: Water lily sign is seen in infection due to _____
questions.solution:
Water lily sign is seen in hydatid cyst, an infection due to Echinococcus granulosus.

Hydatid Cyst is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species (dog tapeworm). Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human-to-human transmission.

The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is mainly asymptomatic until complications occur. The most common presenting symp­toms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

The water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane, resulting in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily, on USG.

questions.text:
A patient with severe persistent asthma continues to have symptoms despite being on high-dose ICS-LABA therapy. Which of the following is a leukotriene receptor antagonist, appropriate as an add-on therapy for this patient?

ICS-LABA : Inhaled corticosteroids - Long acting bronchodilators
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast can be used as an add-on therapy in this patient.

Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. They are competitive antagonists of the cysLT1 receptors. These drugs act by: 

  • Decreasing bronchoconstriction
  • Reducing airway mucus secretion
  • Decreasing vascular permeability and
  • Reducing eosinophil chemotaxis 

Leukotriene modifiers are less effective than inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) in controlling asthma. They are used as add-on therapy in some patients whose asthma is not controlled with low doses of ICS.

Option A: Dupilumab is an interleukin-4 receptor antagonist used in severe asthma. 

Option B: Roflumilast is a PDE-4 selective inhibitor used in the treatment of COPD.

Option D: Zileuton is a lipoxygenase inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: Under McNaughten's rule, which of the following criteria is not valid to clear a mentally unsound person of all responsibility?

choices.text: Psychiatric illness while committing the crime
Inability to understand that the act is wrong

questions.solution:
The criterion of the presence of uncontrollable impulse is not included in McNaughten's rule. Therefore, it is not a valid criterion to clear a mentally unsound person of all criminal responsibility.

McNaughten's rule is followed by the British Courts of law to examine the liability of a mentally unsound person who has committed a crime. Sec. 84 IPC (BNS Section 22) is the Indian adaptation of this rule. 

McNaughten's rule forms the basis of the legal test of insanity/the 'right or wrong' test. It states that a mentally unsound person is cleared of all criminal responsibility for the crime committed if the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of evidence of psychiatric illness.
  • Existence of psychiatric illness at the time of the commission of the crime.
  • Psychiatric illness is of such a degree that the person does not have the ability to understand the wrongness of the act, i.e., impaired intellectual ability. 

McNaughten's rule decides a person's soundness of mind based on the presence or absence of intellectual ability. However, it fails to consider any impairments in the person's emotional state or the presence of any uncontrollable/ irresistible impulses while committing the act.

questions.text: Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes do not include
questions.solution:
Waldeyer’s Ring

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer’s ring.

The masses are:

  • Nasopharyngeal tonsil or the adenoids
  • Palatine tonsils or simply the tonsils
  • Lingual tonsil
  • Tubal tonsils (in fossa of Rosenmüller)
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules (in posterior pharyngeal wall)

questions.text: Identify the refractive error shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows parallel rays of light converging at a point in front of the retina. This is seen in myopia.

Definitions of refractive errors:

Myopia—Short-sightedness: The parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focussed in front of the retina when accommodation is at rest.

Hypermetropia—Long-sightedness: The parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused behind the retina when accommodation is at rest.

questions.text: A study was conducted on a group of 500 patients having carcinoma lung and another group of 300 was chosen from the general population. Both these groups were questioned on their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution:
This is a case–control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people constitute the controls, and the study is done from effect to cause as the disease has already occurred.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Easy to carry out

Rapid and inexpensive

Requires few subjects

Used to investigate rare diseases

No risk to subjects

Different etiological factors can be studied.

Risk factors can be identified.

No attrition problems

Minimal ethical problems

Relies on memory or past records which can give rise to bias

Selection of appropriate control groups may be difficult.

Incidence cannot be measured.

Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate.

questions.text: Example of multiphasic screening is _____

choices.text: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
Pap smear in women above 40 years
Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.solution:
Example of multiphasic screening is annual health checkups.

Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time.

High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups example- MRI screening of breast done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in first degree relative .

Pap smears screening as per American Cancer Society (ACS) should start at age 21. Women aged <21 years should not be screened regardless of the age of sexual initiation or other risk factors. 

Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using chest X-ray for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: Given below is an image of a patient with fever and rash. When is the spread of this disease the maximum?

choices.text: Just before and after the onset of rash
One week before onset of rash

questions.solution:
The image depicts the rash of chickenpox, as different stages of the rash can be seen at one time. The communicable period of chickenpox is 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash.

Related Pearl: Period of communicability of important diseases

  • Chicken pox – 1-2 days before to 4-5 days after appearance of rash
  • Tetanus – not communicable
  • Hepatitis B – One month before the appearance of Jaundice till the disappearance of HbsAg
  • Measles- 4 days before to 4 days after appearance of rash
  • Rubella – 7 days before to 7 days after the rash
  • Mumps -4-6 days before to 7 days after symptoms onset
  • Pertussis- 7 days before to 3 weeks after the onset of paroxysms
  • Diphtheria – Up to 4 weeks after disease onset
  • Meningococcal meningitis – till Meningococci are absent from nasal/throat swabs
  • Influenza – 1 to 2 days before and 1 to 2 days after onset of symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for diagnosis of COVID-19?

choices.text: Reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction test

questions.solution:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of Covid-19 is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) during the first week of symptoms.

RT-PCR: This method involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA.

Rapid antigen test (RAT): Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR. 

Antibody testing: Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. During the evaluation, the patient opens his eyes in response to voice and says inappropriate words. He is unable to move his right arm but extends his left arm to a painful stimulus on his right arm. What is the GCS score of this patient?
questions.solution:
The GCS score of the patient described is 8 (E3 V3 M2).

In the case elaborated above, the score allotted is :

  • Eye-opening to speech—3
  • Inappropriate words—3
  • Extensor response to painful stimuli—2

Patients scoring a GCS of 3 or 4 have an 85% chance of dying or remaining vegetative.

However, scores >11 indicate only a 5–10% likelihood of death or vegetative state and an 85% chance of moderate disability or good recovery.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity and rash on her face as seen below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis from the given clinical scenario and image is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

The rash visualized in the image is a malar rash. It is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Cutaneous manifestations seen in SLE are:

  • Acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (malar rash)
  • Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus
  • Discoid lupus erythematosus- DLE (discoid rash)
  • Ulcerations in the oral mucosa
  • Alopecia- It is a non-scarring alopecia in the majority of the cases. However, patients with DLE will have scarring alopecia.

questions.text: A patient comes with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness since 1 hour. Her CT appears normal. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient.

Intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase: 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in window period (within 3/4.5 hours of symptom onset).

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: Type of knot seen in below image is:
questions.solution:
The above given image shows Reef knot.

Note: In granny knot, the second knot (superiormost) is seen to thread in the same direction as compared to the first knot .The knot is therefore not squared

Types of knot:

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the hospital for the management of breast cancer. The tumor is 3 cm in size with ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes. There is no distant metastasis. The TNM staging of tumor is:
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the tumor is T2 N1 M0.

  • Tumor size 3 cm: T2 
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes: N1
  • No distant metastasis: M0

Points to remember

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm).
  • Skin involvement does not include nipple retraction and skin dimpling.
  • Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump.
  • If lumps are present in both breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: An infant delivered at full-term by normal vaginal delivery, presented with respiratory distress immediately after birth. Chest X-ray showed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The common clinical presentation is as follows:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Dextrocardia
  • Scaphoid abdomen

Prenatal diagnosis is done by ultrasonography. Lung-to-head ratio (LHR) is used to assess severity in patients with left-sided CDH. An LHR value of <1 is associated with a very poor prognosis, whereas an LHR >1.4 predicts a more favourable outcome.

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the aspiration of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which can occur before, during or immediately after birth. Meconium is the first intestinal discharge from newborns, a viscous, dark-green substance composed of intestinal epithelial cells, lanugo, mucus, and intestinal secretions.

Option D: During normal delivery, the compression of the rib cage while passing through the mother's vaginal canal helps to remove fluid from the lungs. However, newborns who are delivered via cesarean birth may have excess fluid in the lungs and therefore be hypoxic and develop transient tachypnea.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: All are true about the inguinal canal except _________.

choices.text: Conjoint tendon forms a part of the posterior wall.
Superficial ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis.
Deep ring is an opening in the transverse abdominis.
Internal oblique forms both the anterior and posterior walls.

questions.solution:
The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia, not in the transverse abdominis.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards and medially.

It extends from deep inguinal ring to superficial ring.

Boundaries:

  • Anterior:
    • External oblique aponeurosis
    • Internal oblique muscle (in lateral 1/3rd)
  • Superior wall/roof:
    • Internal oblique
    • Transverse abdominis
  • Posterior wall:
    • Fascia transversalis
    • Conjoint tendon (Internal oblique + Transverse abdominis)
  • Inferior wall/floor:
    • Inguinal ligament/Poupart ligament (Rolled out Inferior edge of the external oblique aponeurosis and extends from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle)
    • Lacunar ligament at medial end (fan-shaped medial expansion of the inguinal ligament)

Deep inguinal ring: Oval opening in fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring: Triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for check-up following an MTP. On ultrasound, retained tissue was found and the following instrument was used for its removal. What is this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe.

Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done upto 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only upto 10 weeks of gestation . 

The indications of this procedure are given as follows:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy
  • Incomplete abortion or missed abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Endometrial aspiration

questions.text: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is a caesarean section.

There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.

 

The WHO partograph is a repeatedly tested topic in the NBE and Central Institute exams.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed?
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high.

For those who undergo TVUS and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation in abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy is the investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: A woman recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxious and wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally. Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with an absent Barr body?
questions.solution:
Barr body is absent in female having 45 X0 genome.

Barr body

  • Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female is found in the nucleus.
  • Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomes which become inactivated.
  • The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes.

Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body.

Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body.

Note:

  • Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, the other becomes inactive during embryogenesis.
  • Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found in neutrophils of females.

questions.text: Identify the prosthesis in the given image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows thompson prosthesis.

Thompson prosthesis is used in hemiarthroplasty to replace the head of femur. It is specially indicated in cases where neck of femur is absorbed. It can be used with or without cement.

Note: Austin-Moore prosthesis contains two fenestrations in the stem which are for the growth of bone and thompson prosthesis has no fenestrations.

 

 Below X-Ray and the image shows Austin-Moore Prosthesis:

questions.text: A 37-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use stopped drinking. Three days later, he was brought to the emergency department with disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of a chronic alcoholic man brought in with complaints of disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens occurs after 2-4 days of abstinence in a heavy or chronic drinker. It is precipitated by conditions like hepatitis and pancreatitis. It usually resolves in one week. The characteristic clinical features include:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation in time and place
  • Distractibility and lack of attention
  • Visual, auditory, and/or tactile hallucinations
  • Autonomic disturbance with tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating, and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia
  • Insomnia
  • Dehydration with electrolyte imbalance

Delirium tremens is treated using benzodiazepines starting with a higher dosage which is gradually tapered as withdrawal symptoms disappear. In cases of chronic alcohol use, vitamin deficiency (especially thiamine) may be co-existing and hence bolus doses of thiamine are given to prevent/treat Wernicke encephalopathy.

Other options:

Option A- Alcoholic hallucinosis is characterized by the presence of hallucinations (usually auditory) during partial or complete abstinence. However, the other symptoms given in the clinical scenario are not seen.

Option B- Korsakoff’s psychosis: It is seen n patients with chronic alcohol use usually followed by Wernicke’s encephalopathy, together referred to as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Patients with Korsakoff's psychosis present with memory disturbances, which is not seen in the given case.

Option C- Marchiafava-Bignami disease is a rare disorder seen in chronic alcoholics, associated with epilepsy, ataxia, dysarthria, hallucinations, spastic limb paralysis, and deterioration of personality and intellectual functioning.

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Manifestation
Symptoms/signs
Onset since last drink (hours)
Tremulousness
Continuous tremor of > 8 Hz (or) Bursts of tremor activity < 8 Hz
6–8
Alcoholic hallucinosis/
Psychotic and perceptual symptoms
Visual, auditory or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs. 
8-12
Seizures (rum fits)
Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic
12–24
Delirium tremens
Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, impaired orientation
< 72

questions.text: Identify the device shown below:
questions.solution:
The image shown above is of Lack's circuit, which is a co-axial modification of Mapleson's A circuit.

Co-axial circuits have two tubings, one inner and one outer tubing (arranged co-axially).

Lack's circuit has:

  • Inner expiratory tubing: carries exhaust gases out through APL valve
  • Outer inspiratory tubing: carries fresh gas flow to the patient

Co-axial circuits: Bain's vs Lack's circuit

Magill's circuit (Mapleson A) designed by Sir Ivan Magill, best suited for spontaneous ventilation.

Jackson and Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is a modification of Ayre's T piece. Best suited for children under 20 kg.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with an increased nighttime itching and lesions that are more during the winter months?
questions.solution:
Skin lesions that increase during the winter months and that cause more itching during the nighttime are seen with scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic skin infection that is transmitted through the means of close personal contact/fomites. It is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis or human itch mite. It leads to severe pruritis, excoriating papules, and burrows. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared. Typical sites include the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, and genitalia. The typical lesions of scabies are burrows.

The following techniques can be used to diagnose scabies:

  • Skin scraping and microscopy - The material is scraped off with a blunt scalpel and is placed in mineral oil on a microscope slide. The presence of mites, eggs, fragments of eggshells, or scybala (hardened masses of faeces) confirms the diagnosis.
  • Dermoscopy - Useful for detecting burrows and visualizing their contents.
    • 10x magnification - mini triangle sign, maturing eggs that show minute heads of maturing mites within the egg.
    • 40x magnification - The mite in its burrow resembles a ‘jet‐with‐contrail’.
  • Adhesive-tape test - After firmly applying the adhesive side of the tape onto an appropriate skin lesion of patient, the tape is pulled off and transferred directly onto a slide for microscopy to visualize the mites.
  • Skin biopsy.

Treatment:

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% Lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.
  • Ivermectin and benzyl benzoate are contraindicated in pregnancy.

The image below shows a photo of a scabies burrow. The large scaly patch at the left is due to scratching. At the upper right, the scabies mite can be seen at the end of the burrow.

The Sarcoptes scabies mite is shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with tinea infection present with circular plaques with a sharp margin and raised edges that are itchy. 

The image below shows a lesion in tinea corporis.

Option C: Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scale, commonly affecting extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. It is often associated with nail changes and may involve systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis. Given below is an image of plaque psoriasis.

Option D: Photodermatosis refers to a group of skin conditions caused or exacerbated by exposure to sunlight or UV radiation. It can result in rashes, itching, or other skin reactions, often requiring sun protection or medical treatment.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below which is the investigation of choice in distal bowel tumours.
questions.solution:
Enteroclysis, which is the investigation of choice in patients with small bowel tumors.

Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube.

Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging of the entire small intestine.

Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumors and is the investigation of choice, particularly for tumors located in the distal small bowel.

Advantages of enteroclysis:

  • The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus.
  • The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, the following can be visualized:
    • Mild strictures
    • Small sinus tracts and fistulas
    • Minimal extrinsic compressions
    • Skip lesions
    • Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
  • The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a natural source of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
X-rays are not a natural source of radiation exposure. They are artificially produced by linear accelerators.

Sources of radiation exposure:

Natural:

  • Cosmic rays
  • Environmental - terrestrial and atmospheric
  • Radioactive isotopes - of potassium (K-40) and carbon (C-14)

Man-made:

  • Medical and dental - X-rays, radioisotopes
  • Occupational exposure
  • Nuclear - radioactive fallout
